statement: I think the Electoral College still has an important role in making sure smaller states and rural areas like much of Pennsylvania aren’t completely drowned out by big coastal cities, so I wouldn’t scrap it. That said, I’d support reforms that keep it fair and transparent—like tightening rules around how electors are chosen, making it harder for them to go “faithless,” and encouraging states to allocate their electors in a way that better reflects the will of their voters while still preserving a state-based system.

That kind of change would make candidates pay more attention to healthcare, education, and working families everywhere, not just in a few swing states.

statement: As someone who believes in fairness and accountability, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every citizen’s ballot counts equally, no matter what state they live in. It doesn’t sit right with me that a candidate can win the presidency without winning the most votes, especially when Black voters and other minorities are often concentrated in states that get taken for granted. A straightforward popular vote would push candidates to earn support from people everywhere, not just in a handful of swing states.

statement: As a citizen and voter, I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot carries equal weight, no matter what state you live in. If a full replacement isn’t politically feasible, I’d support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact or proportional allocation of electors as meaningful steps in the right direction.

statement: At my age, having lived through many elections both in Ireland and here in the States, I’ve come to feel the Electoral College no longer reflects the will of the people. I’d like to see it replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot, whether cast in a big city or a small town, counts equally. If that’s politically out of reach, then at least states should allocate electors proportionally instead of winner‑take‑all, so candidates have to earn broad support rather than just focusing on a handful of swing states.

statement: I think the Electoral College should be changed so that the popular vote matters more, because it feels unfair that someone can win the presidency without getting the most votes. Maybe we could keep parts of it but make it so electoral votes are divided based on how people in each state actually vote, instead of winner-take-all. That way, everyone’s vote would feel like it counts, including people in smaller states like Wisconsin.
